ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Basica linear algebra concepts: matrices, row operations, examples of applications.
Matrix operations, markov chains, approximations, eigenvectors/values, other applications
Knowledge of using linear algebra to solve problems and its application in real life.
Learned calculations essential to linear algebra -- matrix algebra, bases subspaces, etc
Super theoretical math course. Dont recommend if you hate letters

How to manipulate matrices. Various theorems involving linear algebra. How to more efficiently solve problems and systems of equations using matrices and other tools such as markov chains or inverting matrices
Operations related to matrices and how to apply them to real-world trends
I learned how to do a lot of the computational tools in linear algebra, and I also got a better handle on linear algebra concepts.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Would have appreciated walking through more examples before just trying to do them on our own knowing only the theorems and stuff because it was basically a waste of time most of the time we didn't even know where to start.

Strengths very organized and the problem sets were perfect  challenging enough but by no means impossible. Weaknesses could use slides or have some form of online notes; not just definitions but also more practice application problems during class

Strengths: there were enough office hours, psets were fair
Weaknesses: teaching wasn't very comprehensible or accessible
Learning was tough and not explained well

There was a severe lack of instruction for assignments that were very important to our grade, such as the application project. I didn't feel very supported during lectures or with the course material, the instructors felt kind of disconnected from the class itself.
TA hours were extremely helpful. Simpler and more direct teaching
The content is relatively easy to grasp and the PSETs are manageable.
Recorded lectures or smaller review videos would be helpful when review our notes to study. The book is helpful but explains things differently than both professors did.
Please please please never do the project again. Was so much harder and more time consuming than doing another midterm and I felt I didnt learn anything from it
The in-class activities/problems were a strength, and the class could be improved by giving more of those out.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Depends on their academic interest. It was good background for a lot of fields but I wouldn't recommend to take it randomly.

Yes! Learned a lot of linear algebra which is generally well-understood and applicable to so many fields. Unlike MATH 225, which many friends have taken, proofs don't shroud the application of the techniques in this course, while we still obtain a good understanding of why things are the way they are.
Yes
Unsure; professor seemed a bit hesitant at first and also too formulaic. concepts were not taught in a very understandable way
Nah. I did bad and it was hard to do good
Definitely, book is very easier to understand. Skills are fundamental for further learning. Project is fun and engaging
Yes, it's a low-stress way to learn about linear algebra and you have the opportunity to apply it in an applications project.
Yes, if it is required for their major or if they are looking for an easier way to get into linear algebra than 225/226.
